results.title: Jazz mania
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Chris Hubbard
results.brief_description: This production takes a look at the impact of Jazz on people and society when it was firstly introduced in the 1920’s. Incorporating archival footage with dramatised scenes resembling newsreels of the time, the film documents the shock and consternation registered by polite society.

results.title: Jazz jukebox: the Snader Telescriptions 1951-52
results.brief_description: This is an amazing collection of 17 rare, high quality, music clips from 1951-52 capturing some of the major artists of the day including Bob Crosby & the Bobcats (March of the Bobcats), Teresa Brewer (Music, music, music), Peggy Lee (What more can a woman do?), Nat King Cole (Little girl), Jack Teagarden & his Allstars (Jack Armstrong blues) and The Weavers (Goodnight Irene). The 3-minute clips were originally produced as television fillers by Snader Telescriptions but have since proven to be an invaluable and historical record of the pre rock’n’roll music scene of the fifties.

results.title: Jazz in the concert hall. Parts 1 and 2
results.creator_credit: Columbia Broadcasting System and Roger Englander
results.brief_description: Leonard Bernstein explains and illustrates the nature of jazz and its fusion with serious concert music since the 1920’s. Includes three major works performed by the New York Philharmonic Orchestra and soloists to illustrate this fusion: Gunther Schuller’s “Journey into jazz” featuring jazz musicians Don Ellis (Itrumpet), Eric Dolphy (alto sax), Benny Golsen (tenor sax), Richard Davis (bass) and Joseph Cocuzzo (drums); Aaron Copland’s “Concerto for piano and orchestra”; Larry Austin’s “Improvisations for orchestra and jazz soloists”.

results.title: Jazz in exile
results.creator_credit: Francerelli Film Productions and Chuck France
results.brief_description: Filmclips of American jazz performances and interviews with musicians are used to discuss why America has failed to appreciate its most prominent, indigenous art form. Why have so many artists left and settled in Europe and why have some gone home in the last few years? Musicians featured: Dexter Gordon, Johnny Griffin, Steve Lacy, Randy Weston, Phil Woods, Art Farmer, Richard Davis, Gato Barberie, Carla Bley, Freddie Hubbard, Mal Waldron.

results.title: Jazz greats: from Louis Armstrong to Duke Ellington (PC)
results.brief_description: SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS: 386-25 computer or better with 4MB of RAM, MPC CD-ROM player, S-VGA graphics card (640x480x256 colours) with compatible monitor, MPC compliant sound card, mouse, Windows 3.1. Using text, sound bytes and images, this CD ROM traces the history of jazz from Louis Armstrong to Duke Ellington. Chapters can be read on screen and cover big band jazz, jazz piano in the 1930s and 1940s, the New Orleans scene and women in jazz. A video gallery includes performances by Louis Armstrong in his first European tour, Duke Ellington and His Band performing “Sophisticated lady”, Count Basie and “I Left my baby” for the CBS TV broadcast of ‘The Sound of Jazz’ and Billie Holiday singing “Fine and mellow” at the same broadcast. There are discussions with jazz critic and historian Dr. Herb Wong as well as with musicians Dave Brubeck, Tee Carson and Shorty Rogers. Also included are the following songs as sound bytes: Jelly Roll Morton, “Black bottom stomp”; Louis Armstrong, “West end blues”; Coleman Hawkins, “Body and soul”; Duke Ellington, “Take the A train”; Johnny Hodges, “Jeep’s blues”; Bennie Goodman and Charlie Christian, “Breakfast feud”; Gene Krupa and Roy Eldridge, “Rockin’ chair”; Count Basie, “One o’clock jump”; Count Basie and Lester Young, “Lester leaps in”; James P. Johnson, “Carolina shout”; Fats Waller, “Aint misbehavin’”; Art Tatum, “Tea for two”; Bessie Smith, “Down hearted blues”; “Billie Holiday, “He’s funny that way”. The disk also contains a bibliography.

results.title: Jazz
results.creator_credit: Florentine Films, WETA-TV, BBC and Ken Burns
results.brief_description: JAZZ is a comprehensive 4 volume series directed by Ken Burns that presents a detailed history of the musical form from its beginnings in the early 19th Century to its development up to the present day. Researched and produced over a six year period it is a thorough and broad study of the history of Jazz and its musicians and includes musicians’ biographies, renowned and rare recordings, footage of live performances, interviews with artists, historians, writers and critics and rare film clips and still photographs that form an extraordinary mix of interpretations of and insight into the characters, origins, development, techniques and reshaping of the diverse musical form that is Jazz.

results.title: Jaws [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Universal Pictures, Richard Zanuck, David Brown and Steven Spielberg
results.brief_description: A killer great white shark is creating havoc at a Long Island Beach. Facing opposition and denial from the town’s Council, the Police Chief (Roy Scheider) decides to search for, and destroy, the killer shark himself. Based on Peter Benchley’s novel, the film grabs audience attention from its opening scene to the closing credits and the suspense and terror never lets up. Skilfully edited and directed, the film set director Spielberg onto the path of fame and fortune. “Jaws” is a consummate cinematic thriller. With Richard Dreyfuss and Robert Shaw. The chilling score is by John Williams.
